column4: Hey, can someone help me understand the concept of runlevels, especially in the context of upstart?
After doing some research I kind of figured out that a runlevel is like a "mode of operation" of the OS. So there's a runlevel for single-user-operation, shutting down, restarting etc.
But quite a few upstart scripts I've seen look like they're using arbitrary runlevels like "1234"
I mean I understood the significance of running at runlevels 0-6. What about ones beyond that?
Ubuntu does not use anything past runlevel 6
seen that? because it explains that Debian and Ubuntu do not use anything past runlevel 6.
For example, here's an upstart script https://gist.github.com/970181 for running gunicorn. 2345 sounds like it's completely random and above 6.
So this basically says, "start gunicorn when the system boots up, stop it when it shuts down", right?
start this thing up as long as the system is not in single-user mode or rebooting,:
